abstract:
Hands on Demo! Get ready to get excited about Cassandra, Spark, Jupyter,
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Data Science, and Python!

Requirements: Some knowledge of python, some knowledge of databases,
''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''

some knowledge of Jupyter, experience of installing Linux based software
on your laptop. Windows users might want to have a Linux based VM ready
to be used for this. Must be able to install on laptop, or just happy to
sit and follow along.

-  15 minute presentation on "What is Apache Cassandra/DataStax
   Enterprise, What is Apache Spark, and What is Sentiment Analysis"
-  30 minutes Installing DataStax Enterprise and Jupyter on laptops
-  10 minutes setting up a Twitter Dev account (People may also choose
   to just get data from provided CSV files)
-  5 minutes installing dependencies (pandas, numpy etc)
-  15 minutes walking through Jupyter notebook together
-  15 minutes exploring, questions, and wrap up discussion "How could we
   have gotten better results etc?"

By the end of the 90 minutes everyone should be able to run the notebook
''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''

independently, have Cassandra (DataStax Enterprise) installed, explore
other topics (changing search terms etc)
description:
In this tutorial, we’ll use sentiment analysis on Twitter data about the
latest movie titles to answer that age old question: “Is that movie any
good?” We’ll show how we built the solution using Apache Cassandra,
Apache Spark, DataStax Enterprise Analytics, Python and Jupyter
notebooks. This is a great tutorial to attend if you are new to big data
or want to learn more about Cassandra and Spark!
title: When Rotten Tomatoes Isn’t Enough: Analyzing Twitter Movie Reviews Using DataStax Enterprise
